titleStmt.title: Social network analysis-based consensus-supporting framework for large-scale group decision-making with incomplete interval type-2 fuzzy information

analytic.title: Social network analysis-based consensus-supporting framework for large-scale group decision-making with incomplete interval type-2 fuzzy information

biblStruct.note: Received date: 21 September 2018 Revised date: 15 May 2019 Accepted date: 19 June 2019 Preprint submitted to Information Sciences

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Experts are assumed to be mutually independent and incomplete decision matrices are used, in traditional large-scale group decisionmaking (LSGDM). Social network analysis (SNA) methods are useful for managing LSGDM problems considering the social relationships among experts. This study develops a novel SNA-based decision framework for addressing LSGDM problems with incomplete interval type-2 fuzzy information. First, a community detection algorithm is designed to classify experts, and a trust propagation and aggregation mechanism is developed to obtained experts indirect trust values and weights based on the social trust network. Second, a multi-objective programming model integrated with trust relationships among experts is constructed to estimate the missing values in incomplete interval type-2 fuzzy decision matrices. The proposed estimation approach is robust and effectively estimates missing values while maintaining high discrimination levels. Subsequently, an SNA-based consensus-reaching model is designed for achieving a group consensus based on a twofold feedback adjustment mechanism, namely, adaptive judgment and weight feedback. Finally, an illustrative example is presented to demonstrate the applicability of the proposed approach. A simulation and comparison study is conducted to verify the efficiency and advantages of the SNA-based consensus-supporting framework for LSGDM.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
Highlights
div.p: • We design a community detection algorithm to reduce the dimension of social trust network with large-scale experts.
• We propose interval type-2 fuzzy trust propagation and aggregation operators to establish trust relationships between experts in indirect contact.
• We construct a SNA-based multi-objective programming model to estimate missing preference values in interval type-2 fuzzy decision matrices.
• We proposed a SNA-based consensus-supporting framework with a two-fold feedback adjustment mechanism for achieving consensus.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Group decision making (GDM) is a type of participatory procedure in which two or more decision makers (DMs) or experts collectively achieve a common solution for a decision-making problem [10]. As the complexity of the decision object and the information that is involved increases, more stakeholders participate in the decision process, and integrated group knowledge will be more helpful to understand the decision that is made [13]. When decisions must be made by a large number of stakeholders, it is referred to as large-scale GDM (LSGDM) 5 [25]. The main characteristics of LSGDM problems are their uncertainty, complexity and intra-group conflicts, which can potentially lead to unmotivated DMs and non-cooperation [25].

Language is the most direct and effective tool for DMs to express their assessment information due to its convenience and closeness to peoples true feelings. Zadeh [45] proposed the concept of linguistic terms. Accordingly, several types of fuzzy sets, such as type-1 fuzzy sets [2], intuitionistic fuzzy sets [31] and interval type-2 fuzzy sets (IT2FSs) [6], have been employed to translate linguistic ratings 10 into numerical expressions. As more parameters are involved in IT2FSs, the information in linguistic terms can be well retained, which can yield accurate results in the process of determining linguistic terms [22]. Hence, IT2FSs are suitable for capturing the uncertainty and vagueness of linguistic terms. As the basic elements of IT2FSs, interval type-2 fuzzy numbers (IT2FNs) have been widely used to model linguistic decision information in GDM and LSGDM [3]. Qin et al. [27] developed an extended interval type-2 fuzzy TODIM (an acronym in Portuguese of interactive and multi-criteria decision making) to address multi-criteria GDM (MCGDM) problems. Chen and Kuo [4] 15 proposed a new MCGDM method for autocratic decision-making based on IT2FNs, enhanced Karnik-Medel (KM) algorithms and the ordered weighted averaging (OWA) operator. Moreover, Wu et al. [40] developed a solution to solve interval type-2 fuzzy double LSGDM problems.

Although numerous methods have been proposed to solve interval type-2 fuzzy GDM and LSGDM problems, limitations exist. First, almost all of these methods for coping with interval type-2 fuzzy GDM and LSGDM problems require DMs to provide complete assessments 20 over all the available alternatives. Given the time pressure, the lack of domain knowledge, or their limited expertise, DMs providing complete assessments in some decision situations is unrealistic, especially those involving numerous alternatives or conflicting and dynamic sources of information. Second, no measure is designed to eliminate the intra-group conflicts among DMs under an acceptable level before deriving the group solution. In this sense, experts may not accept the group solution because they think that their opinions have not been seriously

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T enough considered. 25 Various estimation methods have been developed within the context of fuzzy preference relations [1,17], linguistic preference relations [49] and linguistic distribution assessments [46] to cope with incomplete assessments. These estimation methods are based on iterative algorithms or motivated by programming models, which are highly dependent on the known preference information that is provided by DMs. If the preference values are ignorant, then these estimation methods become ineffective [17]. Moreover, these estimation methods are suitable for solving various GDM problems with fuzzy sets, linguistic term sets, hesitant fuzzy linguistic term sets and linguistic distribution 30 assessments. Whether they are applicable to LSGDM problems with IT2FNs requires further verification.

A frequently used method is implementing a consensus-reaching process (CRP) to obtain a collective solution that is as close as possible to a unanimous agreement to eliminate the conflict among DMs by reducing it under an acceptable degree [9,16,20,26,30]. Solutions have been proposed to provide support in LSGDM contexts [13]. Various clustering methods, such as fuzzy c-means [15] and self-organizing maps [25] have been applied to reduce the necessary number of large-scale experts and improve the efficiency of CRPs. For the feedback and 35 adjustment in the CRPs in LSGDM, most methods based on the judgment feedback mechanism (JFM) modify the judgments of the experts or clusters [15,17,34], and a control parameter is set to determine how much of the judgment is inherited from the original judgment. Other methods based on the weight feedback mechanism (WFM) modify the weights of the experts or clusters [41], and the incompatible experts weights are reduced in each iteration.

Practically, for the JFM-based CRP methods, identifying the exact value for the control parameter is difficult and the value is generally 40 fixed in each iteration, which cannot reflect the actual decision making situations cautiously. For the WFM-based CRP methods, only DMs who hinder the group consensus are punished for their incompatible behaviors while other DMs who promote the group consensus are not rewarded for their positive behaviors. In this sense, several DMs may think that their contributions do not receive as much attention as they perhaps deserve and take negative actions (for example, non-cooperative behaviors) in the following discussion. Moreover, most consensusbased methods for LSGDM regard DMs as independent individuals who have no relationships with other members. In practice, most DMs 45 in an LSGDM problem are stakeholders or have several types of relationships in the problem being solved. This idea implies that the social relationships among DMs who participate in the same LSGDM may have been already established. Thereby, the assessments of DMs with respect to alternatives may be influenced by others [17]. Therefore, when the relationships of DMs are arranged in a social network structure
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: that is characterized by various social relationships, the traditional methods for LSGDM that focus exclusively on analyzing preference information in order to achieve a consensus are no longer sufficient in some real-word domains.
Social network analysis (SNA) has become one of the most popular methodologies for investigating social relationships among members.

SNA provides a way to reveal the interconnections among individuals; in it, an expert is easily influenced by his/her most trusted experts in the social network, thereby affecting the result of the GDM [7,8,32]. Related studies have presented the advantages of SNA-based methods for dealing with the complexity of GDM and LSGDM problems [17,18,29,39,48]. Two mainstream SNA-based consensus approaches have been developed to achieve the predefined consensus level (CL) in GDM and LSGDM. In the first mainstream research methods, the 55 SNA-based CRPs are in static social networks [17,18,29]. In the second mainstream research methods, the SNA-based CRPs are in dynamic social networks [48]. The former regards the social network as a reliable source to identify the weights of the DMs or estimate the missing values that are not provided by several DMs. The latter adjusts the weights of the DMs by revising the trust assessments in the social network. Moreover, SNA-based clustering methods have been developed to reduce the dimension of large-scale DMs within the context of IT2FNs [39]. However, no CRPs are considered in these interval type-2 fuzzy LSGDM methods, which are not feasible or sufficient in 60 practical situations.

In summary, despite the pioneer research proposing various LSGDM models, they still suffer from limitations. Concretely, our interest focuses on investigating the following three challenges for LSGDM problems with IT2FNs in a social network-driven setting.
(1) Only a few models of LSGDM consider the characteristics and inherit diversity of the social relationships among DMs.
(2) Almost no models consider the situations where DMs may provide incomplete assessments within the context of LSGDM with IT2FNs.

(3) Traditional consensus-reaching methods for LSGDM only adjust the preference values or weights of DMs, which are not cautious enough to consider the personalized characteristics of each DM when achieving a consensus. Moreover, little attention has been paid to developing effective consensus-reaching methods for LSGDM with IT2FNs.

On the basis of the motivations that are summarized above, this study draws on SNA to develop a novel decision framework for LSGDM with incomplete interval type-2 fuzzy information. In the proposed framework, DMs elicit trust ratings regarding other DMs in their social 70 network and assessments of a set of alternatives with respect to criteria with linguistic terms, which are then transformed into IT2FNs. For

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: the incomplete IT2FN sociomatrix, trust propagation and aggregation operators are proposed to establish the trust relationships among DMs that are in indirect contact. For the incomplete IT2FN decision matrices, a multi-objective programming model is constructed to estimate missing values. The proposed estimation approach provides a robust and effective solution for addressing the missing values. To support the CRP, this study continues the research line of [29,39] and provides a community detection approach for reducing the dimension of the social 75 trust network with large scale DMs and a weight determination method for identifying the weights of each DM. Thereafter, an SNA-based approach for undertaking the CRP is developed to achieve the predefined CL. A twofold feedback adjustment mechanism, namely, JFM and WFM, is designed to modify the DMs preferences and weights according to their contributions to the group consensus. In this way, every DM can be given a tailored and personalized treatment. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first consensus-supporting approach for LSGDM with incomplete interval type-2 fuzzy information.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section 2 provides the basic concepts about IT2FSs and SNA. Section 3 presents a community detection algorithm, trust propagation and aggregation operators and a corresponding weighting method for DMs. Section 4 develops an SNA-based approach for LSGDM with incomplete interval type-2 fuzzy information. Section 5 presents an illustrative example to demonstrate the application of the proposed approach, which is followed by simulation and comparison experiments in Section 6. Finally, conclusions are drawn in Section 7.

A social network is a social structure consisting of a set of nodes V = {e 1 , e 2 , . . . , e q } and a set of edges L = {l 1 , l 2 , . . . , l N }, where the nodes denote individuals or organizations and the edges denote all different types of relationships between the nodes. 120 Remark 1. The above sociomatrix represents a binary relation among social entities, namely, either total trust or no trust at all exists), which is unsuitable for modeling the uncertainty in a trust relationship representation in a social network [18]. To overcome this limitation, this study attempts to construct a social trust network, in which experts explicitly express their qualitative evaluations about other experts using trust degrees with linguistic terms in the form of IT2FNs. In this situation, the sociomatrix in a social network is called the IT2FN sociomatrix, which is formally defined in Section 3. Graph Sociomatrix Algebraic

div.head: Social trust network with IT2FNs
div.p: This section develops a community detection algorithm and interval type-2 fuzzy trust propagation and aggregation operators for a social trust network with IT2FNs.

div.head: Community detection
div.p: Modularity, which originated from Newman and Girvan [24], is one of the most popular and widely used metrics to evaluate the quality 130 of a networks partition into communities. Larger positive modularity values indicate a better community structure. Leicht and Newman [14] originally proposed an algorithm for detecting the communities in directed networks. The modularity-based method is one of the most common and effective approaches for detecting communities in directed networks [21]. Without the loss of generality, this study extends Leicht and Newman [14]s method for directed networks using IT2FNs because their approach constitutes a generalization of the modularity optimization method [24].

Given a social trust network with a set of experts V e (assume that V is the set of expert subscripts), each expert expresses their trust of other experts using the IT2FNs. The trust strength of e k to expert e l is denoted by tkl , which is defuzzified and expressed as ω kl = C(t kl ) using Eq. ( 5). The problem of dividing a directed network into just two communities must be considered. Here, s k is 1 must be assumed

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: The algorithm for detecting communities or groups in a directed network using the trust information of IT2FNs is presented as follows:
150 Algorithm 1. Community detection for directed network with IT2FNs.
Input: Directed graph G(V, L, S ) with q experts.
Output: Subsets V γ e (γ = 1, 2, . . . , g) of the expert set V e .
Step 1: Calculate the defuzzified trust strength ω kl = C(t kl ) of e k to expert e l by referring to Eqs. ( 5) and ( 6).

Step 2: Calculate the trust strength ω out k = l∈V ω kl of expert e k to the other experts, the trust strength ω in l = k∈V ω kl of the other experts to expert e h and the total strength ω = k∈V ω out k = l∈V ω in l .
Step 3: Construct the modularity matrix B = (B kl ) q×q , where B kl = ω kl -
div.formula: ω out k ω in l ω .
div.p: Step 4: Find the most positive eigenvalue of the symmetric matrix B + B T and the corresponding eigenvector and assign each expert to one of two groups depending on the sign of the appropriate element of the eigenvector.
Step 5: Subdivide the communities using the same method except with the submatrix B in Eq. ( 11 Step 7: Output subsets V γ e (γ = 1, 2, . . . , g) of the expert set V e .

Remark 2. Algorithm 1 can be used to divide a group of experts into several subclusters based on the trust relationships among them. This study does not consider overlapping communities, namely, every expert only belongs to one cluster due to the characteristics of Algorithm 155 1 and the issued LSGDM problem. It should be noted that the trust evaluations between experts are defuzzified based on the KM algorithm

[11] before implementing Algorithm 1. The KM algorithm-based method has been employed to obtain the crisp values of IT2FNs due to its mature characteristics, which can preserve the original decision information as soon as possible. Compared with traditional clustering methods [15,25] in LSGDM, the proposed community detection method can make full use of the trust relationships among experts. It can

div.p: effectively reduce the necessary number of members in LSGDM within the context of a social network.
A numerical example is presented to illustrate the application of Algorithm 1 for detecting communities.

div.head: Determining the weights of experts
div.p: In a directed graph, the in-degree of centrality can be used to determine the importance of nodes in the network [36]. Definition 8. Let G = (V, L, S ) be a directed graph, V e = {e 1 , e 2 , . . . , e q } be a set of nodes and V be the corresponding set of node subscripts, 205 and L = {l 1 , l 2 , . . . , l N } be the set of directed lines (or arcs) between pairs of nodes, in which S = { S 1 , S 2 , . . . , S N } is the set of IT2FN trust assessments that are attached to the lines (or arcs), and T = (t kl ) q×q is the IT2FN sociomatrix associated with G = (V, L, S ). The relative node in-degree centrality index that is obtained from the sociomatrix is defined as follows:
div.formula: Ck d = 1 q -1 q l=1,l k tlk .(17)
div.p: Evidently, a large value of Ck d indicates a high importance degree of node e k as a result of the high overall degree of trust by the remaining nodes in the group. Following this idea, the weight of node e k can be calculated.
div.formula: ω k = C( Ck d ) q k =1 C( Ck d ) ,(18)
div.p: where C( Ck d ) is the average centroid value of IT2FN Ck d as per Eqs. ( 5) and ( 6). Remark 3. The in-degrees of the centrality indices in the form of IT2FNs are obtained using Eq. (17). Conventionally, they can be used to indicate the importance degrees of each expert and can be directly incorporated into the aggregation to obtain the overall evaluation of experts 215 without the CRP in GDM. In this study, the CRP is considered and a twofold feedback mechanism, namely, JFM and WFM, is applied to support the CRP. Particularly, the WFM is adopted to adjust the weights of the experts. Thus, the defuzzification and normalization of Eq. ( 18) are necessary before implementing the following CRP of LSGDM in this study.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
SNA-based approach for LSGDM with incomplete interval type-2 fuzzy information
div.p: This section presents a SNA-based approach for solving LSGDM problems with incomplete interval type-2 fuzzy information. The 220 proposed approach consists of three main parts, namely estimating the missing values, achieving a consensus and selecting the best alternative(s).

For simplicity, let A = {a 1 , a 2 , . . . , a m } be a set of m alternatives, C = {c 1 , c 2 , . . . , c n } be a set of n criteria, and w = (w 1 , w 2 , . . . , w n ) T be the criterion weight vector, where 0 ≤ w j ≤ 1 and n j=1 w j = 1. w j denotes the weight of criterion c j , and V e = {e 1 , e 2 , . . . , e q } is a set of q (q ≥ 20) experts. Each expert provides ratings of the alternatives with respect to each criterion and trust evaluations of the other experts 225 using linguistic terms in the form of IT2FNs. Assume that Rk = (r k i j ) m×n (k = 1, 2, . . . , q) is the IT2FN decision matrix, where rk i j indicates expert e k 's preference for alternative a i with respect to criterion c j , and T = (t kl ) q×q is the IT2FN sociomatrix, where tkl denotes the trust strength of expert e k on expert e l . In LSGDM, several experts may not provide full evaluations and the corresponding decision matrices are incomplete since some preference values are missing.
The following parts are presented to solve the above LSGDM problem.

div.head: Estimation of missing evaluation values
div.p: Wu et al. [38] proposed a trust-based method to estimate the missing values in multi-criteria decision matrices. Although the trust relationships among experts are reliable sources for estimating missing values, the discrimination of the expert is overlooked. The discrimination, which is a necessary condition for expertise, refers to the skill of an expert to distinguish between cases that are similar but not completely equivalent. An expert with this ability could tell the minor differences among alternatives, whereas the others could not in 235 regard to evaluating different alternatives in decision making. Thus, this study estimates the missing values of an expert who provides an incomplete decision matrix combining his/her discrimination and the overall evaluations of his/her trusted experts.

The following sets are first introduced for the sake of clarity. AV k = (i, j) i = 1, 2, . . . , m; j = 1, 2, . . . , n (k = 1, 2, . . . , q), KV k = (i, j) rk i j is known value ∧(i, j) ∈ AV k } and MV k = (i, j) rk i j is missing value ∧ (i, j) ∈ AV k , where AV k is the set of all evaluation values, KV k is the set of all known evaluation values and MV k is the set of all missing or unknown evaluation values of the alternatives with respect to the criteria in the IT2FN decision matrix Rk = (r k i j ) m×n and AV k = KV k MV k . Given the missing value rk i j in Rk , T E k i j = {e l |l = 1, 2, . . . , q k ; l k } is the set of expert e k 's trusted experts who can provide complete preference values for rl i j (l = 1, 2, . . . , q k ; l k). In certain GDMs, the importance degree of each expert is known in advance or derived via a reliable source. In Refs. [29,38], the trust evaluations between experts are regarded as a measure of experts' importance because trust reflects the actual reputation of an expert among peers on the basis of their historical actions and behavior. Inspired by the induced OWA (IOWA) operator [44], this study proposes a trust 245 IOWA aggregation operator to obtain the overall evaluation of the trusted experts. ) (l = 1, 2, . . . , q k ) be a collection of IT2FNs given by q k experts who are trusted by expert e k and Ω is the set of all given IT2FNs. Yager [43] proposed the following parameterized family of regular increasing monotonic (RIM) quantifiers Q(x) = x α α ∈ [0, 1]. α is an attitudinal parameter reflecting the attitude of the expert. The lower value of α is, the closer the IOWA aggregation operator that is guided

This parameterized family of RIM quantifiers will be used to identify the weights of the IOWA aggregation operator in the rest of this paper. Without the loss of generality, the quantifier Q(x) = x 0.5 that is used to model the fuzzy quantifier "most" [44] is adopted in this study. Moreover, one can refer to Ref. [43] for the further study on choosing the 260 suitable linguistic quantifier.

Example 3. Suppose that Jack, who is denoted by e k wants to buy a smart cellphone. Since Jack has minimal knowledge about smart cellphones, three of his socially networked friends, who are denoted by e l (l = 1, 2, 3) and who know a lot about electronic products, are invited to provide suggestions. They provide their ratings using linguistic terms, which are then transformed into IT2FNs by referring to Table 2. Assume that the trust assessments that are given by Jack (e k ) for his friends are tkl (l = 1, 2, 3) and the overall ratings that are
provided by e l (l = 1, 2, 3) for a given smart cellphone are rl (l = 1, 2, 3). They are expressed as follows:

The application of the quantifier Q(x) = x 0.5 , which is used to model the fuzzy qualifier "most" [44], yields the following weights: λ σ(1) = 0.6356, λ σ(2) = 0.2302 and λ σ(3) = 0.1342.
According to Eq. ( 19), the overall evaluation of the three friends e l (l = 1, 2, 3) is the following

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: Inspired by the idea of the maximizing deviation method [35], the overall deviation among alternatives is defined to measure the 275 discrimination of an expert.
Definition 11. The discrimination measure Dis(e k ) for expert e k is defined as follows:
div.formula: Dis(e k ) = 1 m(m -1) n j=1 m i1=1 m i2=1,i2 i1 w j d(r k i1 j , rk i2 j ),(21)
div.p: where w j is the weight of criterion c j and d(r k i1 j , rk i2 j ) is the rank-based distance measure between IT2FNs rk i1 j and rk i2 j , as per Eq. ( 7). From the view of ranking the alternatives, a large value of Dis(e k ) indicates obvious differences among alternatives, which plays an important role in choosing the best alternative.

By combining the trust relationships and discrimination, this study constructs a multi-objective programming model to estimate the unknown values of incomplete decision matrices. This model contains two objectives. The first objective is to minimize the sum of deviations between the estimated and the collective values of the trusted experts and the second one is to maximize the discrimination. The idea of this model is that expert e k , who cannot provide a complete decision matrix, can seek preference information from other trusted experts e l (l = 1, 2, . . . , q l ; l k) who can provide complete evaluation values within the social network.
For the estimation of the missing values in Rk = (r k i j ) m×n , the following model is constructed.

Remark 4. The first objective of Eq. ( 22) minimizes the distance between the estimated evaluation values from the trusted experts' evaluation values, which are aggregated using the trust IOWA aggregation operator of Eq. ( 19) to provide recommendations. In this sense, 290 the estimated evaluation values of expert e k , who provides an incomplete decision matrix, might be affected by the values of his/her trusted experts. However, the estimated evaluation values may not guarantee the maximum discrimination degree of expert e k . Thus, the second objective is added, as defined in Eq. ( 21).

Remark 5. The proposed estimation approach is different from existing methods [1,17]. The existing methods are employed to estimate the missing preferences via either the reciprocity and transitivity properties of the preference relations or the trust relationships among experts.

However, the proposed approach is based on a multi-objective programming model. The main advantage of the proposed approach is that the trust relationships among experts are used as reliable searching sources for estimating the missing values while simultaneously maximizing the individual discrimination level.

They can be identified and denoted by the extended linguistic terms by using the approximation methods [28]. In general, the original linguistic terms in Table 1 are expressed by experts and the extended linguistic terms only appear in computation. In this study, the extended linguistic 315 terms are directly characterized using IT2FNs and incorporated into the following calculation.

div.head: Consensus-reaching model for LSGDM
div.p: A consensus-reaching model that divides the large-scale group of experts into several subclusters using the community detection algorithm is designed for LSGDM.

Assume that V γ e (γ = 1, 2, . . . , g) is a set of experts in each subcluster (g is the number of subclusters); q γ and V γ are the number of 320 experts and the set of expert subscripts in subcluster V γ e , respectively; ξ γ k (k ∈ V γ ) and Rk,γ = (r k,γ i j ) m×n are the weight and the IT2FN decision matrix of the k-th expert in subcluster V γ e , respectively; and Bγ = ( bγ i j ) m×n is the collective IT2FN decision matrix of subcluster V γ e .

div.head: Initial weights and decision matrices
div.p: In the CRP, the initial weights of each expert ξ γ k (k ∈ V γ ) in subcluster V γ e and the initial weights of each subcluster ζ γ can be calculated using Eq. ( 18) as follows:
div.formula: 325 ξ γ k = ω k k ∈V γ ω k and ζ γ = k∈V γ ω k .(25)
div.p: The collective IT2FN decision matrix Bγ = ( bγ i j ) m×n of subcluster V γ e and the group collective IT2FN decision matrix R = (r i j ) m×n can be calculated using the interval type-2 fuzzy weighted averaging (IT2FWA) aggregation operator [38] as follows:

div.head: Consensus measures
div.p: Consensus measures are used to evaluate the deviation between experts' individual and group preferences. Consensus measures are used 330 to evaluate the CLs within each subcluster and across subclusters based on the distance measure between IT2FNs, as per Eq.( 7).
Level 1: CL at the element level. The CL CLE k,γ i j of expert e k in subcluster V γ e on alternative a i under criterion c j is
div.formula: CLE k,γ i j = 1 -d(r k,γ i j , bγ i j ). (27

div.formula: CLA k,γ i = n j=1 w j CLE k,γ i j = 1 - n j=1 w j d(r k,γ i j , bγ i j ). (28
div.p: Level 3: CL at the decision matrix level. The CL CL k,γ of expert e k in subcluster
div.formula: V γ e is CL k,γ = 1 m m i=1 CLA k,γ i = 1 - 1 m m i=1 n j=1 w j d(r k,γ i j , bγ i j ).(29)
div.p: Accordingly, the CL CL γ of subcluster V γ e can be defined as follows:
div.formula: CL γ = k∈V γ ξ γ k CI k,γ = 1 - 1 m k∈V γ ξ γ k m i=1 n j=1 w j d(r k,γ i j , bγ i j ).(30)
div.p: A large value of CL γ (0 ≤ CL γ ≤ 1) indicates high agreement among experts in subcluster V γ e . Particularly, CL γ = 1 indicates that the experts in subcluster V γ e reach a complete agreement. Assume that θ is a predefined consensus threshold of an acceptable CL. subcluster V γ e is deemed to reach an acceptable CL if CL γ ≥ θ.

Similarly, as the collective IT2FN decision matrices of each subcluster are obtained, the consensus measures among subclusters can be defined for three levels. The CL of the entire group is defined as follows:
div.formula: 340 GCL = g γ=1 ζ γ CL γ = 1 - 1 m g γ=1 ζ γ k∈V γ ξ γ k m i=1 n j=1 w j d(r k,γ i j , bγ i j ).(31)
div.p: An acceptable CL is reached among subclusters if GCI ≥ θ. When GCI satisfies the minimum threshold θ, the consensus process terminates and an appropriate selection method is applied to achieve the solution of consensus. Otherwise, a recommendation mechanism is implemented to provide preferences to experts.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T

div.head: Twofold feedback adjustment mechanism for LSGDM
div.p: A consensus model with a twofold feedback adjustment mechanism, namely, JFM and WFM, is designed to improve the CL of the 345 experts in a group. This model consists of two main procedures, namely, updating the evaluations after identifying the elements of the alternative values that should be adjusted and updating experts weights according to the contributions of each expert to the group preferences.
The following algorithm is designed to improve the consensus and achieve a predefined GCL.
Algorithm 2. Iterative CRP.

Input: The individual IT2FN decision matrix Rk,γ = (r k,γ i j ) m×n (k ∈ V γ , γ = 1, 2, . . . , g), the weight vectors of the criteria w = (w 1 , w 2 , . . . , w n ) T and experts ω = (ω 1 , ω 2 , . . . , ω q ) T , the predefined threshold θ (0 ≤ θ ≤ 1) and the maximum number of iterations t max (t max ≥ 1).

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T Remark 6. Algorithm 2 contains a twofold feedback adjustment mechanism, namely, JFM and WFM, to modify experts preference values and weights, respectively. Experts whose CLs are lower than are suggested to modify their preference values. The modification is an 380 adaptive preference adjustment according to the experts CLs. Experts whose CLs are lower than and close to will be suggested to revise their preferences to a greater extent. Accordingly, these experts will have an easier time reaching the predefined consensus. The proposed JFM is different from the method in Ref. [41] in which all experts including the experts whose CLs are higher than are required to change their preference values to the corresponding collective ones. Furthermore, the WFM is effective for updating experts weights and rewarding and punishing experts who promote and hamper the group consensus, respectively. 385 Remark 7. Although Algorithm 2 is designed for reaching consensus within subclusters, the algorithm can be applied across subclusters.

In this case, each subcluster is treated as an expert and the collective IT2FN decision matrix Bγ that is output by Algorithm 2 and the initial weights of each subcluster ζ γ that are obtained by Eq. ( 25) will be regarded as input data. Accordingly, the output data will be the final group collective IT2FN decision matrix R = (r i j ) m×n and the CL of the entire group GCL.

div.head: Selection process 390
div.p: The final group collective IT2FN decision matrix R = (r i j ) m×n can be obtained after implementing Algorithm 2 across subclusters. The selection is then developed for R = (r i j ) m×n to obtain the best alternative(s), where ri j = (a U i j1 , a U i j2 , a U i j3 , a U i j4 ; h U ri j ),(a L i j1 , a L i j2 , a L i j3 , a L i j4 ; h L ri j )].
Step 1: Derive the overall assessments of each alternative.

The IT2FWA aggregation operator [39] is used to obtain the collective assessments. ri = n j=1 w j ri j = n j=1 w j a U i j1 , n j=1 w j a U i j2 , n j=1 w j a U i j3 , n j=1 w j a U i j4 ; min{h U ri j } , n j=1 w j a L i j1 , n j=1 w j a L i j2 , n j=1 w j a L i j3 , n j=1 w j a L i j4 ; min{h L ri j } ,
where w j is the weight of criterion c j .
Step 2: Derive the ranking of alternatives and select the best alternative(s).
The centroid value-based ranking method for IT2FNs of Eqs. ( 5) and ( 6) can be used to rank alternatives.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T

div.head: Solution procedure for LSGDM with incomplete interval type-2 fuzzy information
div.p: An SNA-based approach for LSGDM with incomplete interval type-2 fuzzy information is developed on the basis of the aforementioned analysis. The framework of the proposed approach is presented in Figure 3, and the detailed procedures are introduced as follows:
Step 1: Classify the experts into several subclusters.
Implement Algorithm 1 to classify the experts into several subclusters based on the trust relationships among them.
Step 2: Establish indirect trust relationships among experts and obtain the weights of each expert.
Use the trust propagation operator of Eq. ( 13) and the trust aggregation operator of Eq. ( 14) to establish indirect trust relationships among experts. Use Eq. ( 18) to obtain the experts' weights.
Step 3: Estimate the missing values in incomplete decision matrices.
Use Eq. ( 23) to estimate the missing values in incomplete decision matrices.
Step 4: Achieve a consensus for LSGDM.
Implement Algorithm 2 to achieve consensus for LSGDM.
Step 5: Derive the ranking of the alternatives and select the best alternative(s).
Use Eq. ( 36) to obtain the collective evaluations of each alternative and Eqs. ( 5) and ( 6) to rank the alternatives.

div.head: Simulation analysis 510
The design of the simulation
div.p: In the simulation, the initial decision matrices and sociomatrix that are associated with the social trust network are randomly generated.

Particularly, the trust relationships among experts are distinguished using randomly generating trust values from "VL" to "VH", as shown Table 1. The criterion weight vector is w = (0.25, 0.35, 0.4) T . The values are taken as the input of the CRP, based on which the consensus success ratio (P), consensus round (Z) and adjusted distance (AD) can be obtained for measuring the performance of the CRP [47].

Particularly, AD is defined as follows: where AD in and AD ac are the ADs of the CRP within and across subclusters, respectively; d( rk i j , rk i j(0) ) and d( bγ i j , bγ i j(0) ) are the distances between the adjusted and original evaluations within and across subclusters, respectively. This study extends the simulation methods in Ref. [48] within the context of the IT2FN environment. Different from the simulation methods in Ref. [48], if an expert is identified as adopting non-cooperative behaviors, including dishonest, disobedient and divergent 520 behaviors, then his/her weight will be decreased because of his/her small contribution to the group. Meanwhile, the weights of the other experts will be increased according to their respective contributions to the group.
div.formula: AD = 1 2 AD in + AD ac

div.head: Sensitivity analysis results
div.p: In cases of dishonest, disobedient and divergent experts, sensitivity analysis with 147 simulation experiments is conducted to reveal the influence of the number of experts and the weight control parameter σ on the performance of the CRP. We set different input parameters 525 (q = 5, 10, . . . , 35; σ = 1.1, 1.2, . . . , 1.7) and fix R max = 5, m = 4, n = 3, θ = 0.9, g = 2, α 1 = 0.1, β = 0.3, α 2 = 0.02, α 3 = 0.5 and γ = 0.25. We implement the proposed consensus-reaching approach (M1 for short) 1000 times under different input parameters q and σ, and obtain the average values of P, Z and AD, respectively. Figures 567show the average values of P, Z and AD.
From Figures 567, the following observations can be distinguished.

(1) Similar average values of P, Z and AD are obtained although different non-cooperative behaviors exist. Particularly, the consensus 530 success ratios are 1 in most cases with limited adjustment rounds. The results corroborate that the proposed consensus-reaching approach can effectively address dishonest, disobedient and divergent behaviors.

(2) The high value of q and the low value of σ result in large average values of Z and AD. The result is consistent with the logic that more members in GDM naturally add to the complexity of the CRP, and the low value of σ indicates the weak weight adjustment of the experts in each round. Accordingly, the number of iterations and the adjusted distance will increase. 535

div.p: In cases of dishonest, disobedient and divergent experts, comparative analysis with 294 simulation experiments is conducted to compare the proposed consensus-reaching approach (M1 for short) with the non-cooperative behavior management-based consensus-reaching method

div.head: Discussion
div.p: This section presents several simulation and comparison experiments to investigate the efficiency and priorities of the proposed approach. 490

div.head: Effect of the proposed approach for estimating missing values
div.p: The trust relationships among experts are incorporated into the process of estimating the missing values in the proposed approach. The optimal solutions of Eq. ( 23) are regarded as the final estimated preference values. We consider that studies [1,38] derived the overall values of the trusted experts and regarded them as the final estimated preference values by using the weighted averaging aggregation operator, where the weights are identified according to the SNA-based method. In the following, the proposed approach is compared with the aggregation 495 operator-based method for managing incomplete IT2FN decision matrices.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: Take the estimated IT2FNs in R1 as an example. Table 3 shows the estimated IT2FNs and the discrimination of expert e 1 that are yielded by the aggregation operator-based method and the proposed approach. The table also exhibits that the results yielded by the two methods are different. The estimated values that are obtained by the proposed approach can guarantee higher discrimination levels than the aggregation operator-based method. Moreover, the aggregation operator-based method is used to estimate the missing values in other 500 incomplete IT2FN decision matrices. From Figures 8-10, the following observations can be distinguished.

(1) The consensus success ratios of M1 are higher than those of M2 in certain situations because the red mapping surfaces of M1 are higher than the blue mapping grid surfaces of M2, as shown in . Particularly, the consensus success ratios of M1 are 1 in most 545 situations. Hence, the proposed approach can increase the success ratio of achieving the predefined CL by adopting the adaptive JFM and WFM.

(2) The consensus rounds of M1 are lower than those of M2 because the red mapping surfaces of M1 are lower than the blue mapping grid surfaces of M2, as shown in . Hence, the proposed approach can accelerate the convergence speed and achieve the predefined CL.

(3) The adjusted distances of M1 are lower than those of M2 when experts adopt divergent behavior because the red mapping surfaces of M1 are lower than the blue mapping grid surfaces of M2, as shown in Figure 10(c). However, the adjusted distances of M1 are higher than those of M2 when experts adopt disobedient behavior because the red mapping surfaces of M1 are higher than the blue mapping grid surfaces of M2, as shown in Figure 9(c). Although the proposed approach relatively enlarges the modification amount of the incompatible experts' preference information, the approach achieves the predefined CL with a limited number of iterations.

In summary, the proposed approach has the following advantages over existing methods. First, the proposed SNA-based preference estimation approach can effectively estimate the missing values in incomplete IT2FN decision matrices and maintain high discrimination levels. Second, the proposed SNA-based consensus-reaching approach can effectively manage the non-cooperative behaviors in the CRP in the context of LSGDM with IT2FNs. Third, the developed twofold feedback adjustment mechanism, namely, the JFM and WFM of the proposed SNA-based consensus-reaching approach, can accelerate the convergence speed and achieve the predefined CL.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: This study investigates the LSGDM problems with incomplete interval type-2 fuzzy information and develops methods for missing value estimation and CRP based on SNA. The primary features and contributions of the proposed framework are summarized as follows:

(1) A community detection algorithm is designed to reduce the dimension of the social trust network with large-scale experts. Interval type-2 fuzzy trust propagation and aggregation operators are proposed to establish the trust relationships between experts who are in indirect 565 contact. Accordingly, the experts are classified into several subclusters and their weights are obtained based on their trust relationships among them.

(2) An SNA-based estimation method is proposed to estimate the missing preference values in IT2FN decision matrices based on the multiobjective programming model. The comparison results affirm that the proposed approach is robust and effectively estimates missing values by keeping high discrimination levels.

(3) An SNA-based CRP framework is proposed to achieve the predefined CL, in which a twofold feedback adjustment mechanism, namely, JFM and WFM is developed to modify experts' preference values and weights according to their contributions to the group. The simulation and comparative analysis results validate the effectiveness and applicability of the proposed approach for solving LSGDM problems with incomplete interval type-2 fuzzy information.
Meanwhile, several interesting research directions are highlighted for future work. Granular computing [19] is becoming a popular
